I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The proposed loan to Vietnam International Commercial Joint Stock Bank (VIB) will 
provide financing to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) including women-owned and 
women-led SMEs women-led SMEs (WSMEs) and for home improvements and repair. This 
support is particularly timely because of the disproportionate impact that the coronavirus disease 
is having on SMEs. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  Gender disparities in lending to SMEs impede the success of thousands of WSMEs in Viet 
Nam. WSMEs experience an estimated financing gap of $1.2 billion, and only 37% of WSMEs in 
Viet Nam access bank loans, compared to 47% of men-led SMEs. There is generally a lack of 
differentiated marketing approaches in Viet Nam for WSMEs as well as preconceptions that they 
are less profitable, riskier, and less financially savvy. This negatively impacts women’s ability to 
access financing. Social expectations about women’s roles can lead to additional biases.1 
 
3.  To address these issues, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) developed and successfully 
submitted a $14 million grant and technical assistance (TA) funding application to the Women 
Entrepreneurs Finance Initiative (We-Fi) for Viet Nam.2 The application designated approximately 
$4.5 million of the funds to support nonsovereign financial sector transactions, of which $0.5 
million will be allocated to this TA. The loan to VIB is ADB’s first non-sovereign transaction to 
incorporate We-Fi funding.  
 
4.  VIB, like many banks in Viet Nam, does not currently prioritize WSMEs. They are collecting 
limited  information  on  their  WSME  clients  and  cannot  generate  gender-disaggregated 
management information system (MIS) reports. Marketing materials are not oriented to WSMEs, 
loan officers lack training on the specific needs of women clients, and there are opportunities for 
VIB to educate existing and potential WSME clients on how best to present their businesses when 
applying for a loan and what lending products are available. This transaction TA would help VIB 
address these deficiencies.  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
5.  Output 1: Vietnam International Commercial Joint Stock Bank’s financing to small 
and medium-sized enterprises in general and women entrepreneurs in particular expanded. 
VIB plans to target $50 million of the ADB loan for SMEs, including WSMEs. The attached TA will 
collect data on the impact of this lending on a sample of VIB’s WSME clients. This data collection 
is  intended  to  have  a  demonstration  effect  that  will  encourage  VIB  to  develop  more 
comprehensive gender-disaggregated data and to show that WSMEs are bankable clients. It will 
also help VIB, ADB, and other stakeholders better understand how the coronavirus disease is 
impacting WSME businesses. 
 
 
1  International Finance Corporation. 2017. MSME Finance Gap. Assessment of the Shortfalls and Opportunities in 
Financing Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises in Emerging Markets. Washington, DC. 
2  We-Fi is a groundbreaking partnership that aims to unlock financing for women-led and women-owned businesses 
in developing countries. We-Fi’s partners include 14 donor governments, six multilateral development banks as 
implementing partners, and numerous other stakeholders in the public and private sector around the world.

2 
 
6.  Output 2: Vietnam International Commercial Joint Stock Bank’s capacity to serve 
women entrepreneurs strengthened. The TA will help VIB reach women clients through 
developing promotional materials designed to specifically connect with WSMEs. Additionally, the 
TA will work with VIB to develop an online gender-sensitivity training program for its loan officers, 
whose explicit and implicit biases can drive gender disparities in bank lending. The training will 
be designed so that at the end of the TA, VIB will have the capacity to continue the training without 
the support of external consultants. Additionally, VIB will upgrade its MIS to analyze its portfolio 
by gender. This is a precondition for helping VIB to engage women clients more meaningfully in 
the future. 
 
7.  Output 3: Capacity of women entrepreneurs enhanced. Although financial institutions 
may want to lend more to WSMEs, there can be asymmetries between the information that banks 
require to assess a loan application and the information that SMEs, including WSMEs, know how 
to provide. To address this deficiency, VIB is planning at least 10 training seminars around the 
country that will (i) train WSMEs on the various available financial products, (ii) train WSMEs on 
how to prepare loan applications, and (iii) connect WSMEs to local VIB loan officers. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
8.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $500,000  (financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  We-Fi  and 
administered by ADB) plus VIB’s in-kind contributions, such as: staff costs, office costs, related 
taxes and duties...etc.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
9.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 35 months from February 2021 to December 
2023. ADB will administer the TA. Using a One ADB approach, the Viet Nam Resident Mission 
will assume responsibility for TA administration. Implementation arrangements are summarized 
in Table 1.

10.  Consulting services. ADB will engage a consulting firm following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.

3 
 
11.  We-Fi requirements. The TA is aligned with We-Fi’s guidelines. VIB will report to ADB its 
lending to WSMEs against We-Fi’s definition of WSMEs,3 and ADB will update We-Fi on the 
results of the TA annually. A sampling of VIB’s WSME clients and the strengthening of VIB’s MIS, 
which are components of the TA, will support this reporting. 
 
3  Per We-Fi’s definition, WSMEs are defined as borrowing in an amount between $5,000 and $1 million and by either 
(i) being at least 51% owned by women or a woman, or (ii) meeting all of the following 3 sub-criteria: (a) it is at least 
20% owned by a woman or women, (b) a woman is the senior or second most senior executive, and (c) at least 30% 
of the board members are women (where a board exists).
